extracted_ttps.description: Ransomware groups encrypt data to demand payment from victims.
Ransomware attacks on various industries, including IT and Retailers, with a significant increase in the number of victims.
Ransomware can inhibit system recovery by encrypting data or deleting backups.
Ransomware groups manipulate victim data for extortion.
Some ransomware blogs may provide obfuscated victim information.
Threat actors may collect data from local systems during ransomware attacks.
Ransomware groups may exploit public-facing applications to gain initial access.
Data referenced has been processed through automated correlation and enrichment mechanisms
Detected Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Process Injection activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Obfuscated Files or Information activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Exploit Public-Facing Application activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Detection: Data Encrypted for Impact
rules.description: Ransomware groups encrypt data to demand payment from victims.

rules.title: Exploit Public-Facing Application - Ransomware Attack Detection
rules.description: Detects ransomware attacks exploiting public-facing applications, focusing on command line patterns and process creation events.
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration tasks using PowerShell or Command Prompt
Software updates or installations that utilize command line interfaces

rules.title: Inhibit System Recovery via Ransomware
rules.description: Detects ransomware attempts to inhibit system recovery by deleting backups or encrypting data

rules.title: Ransomware Data Manipulation Detection
rules.description: Detects ransomware data manipulation techniques based on process creation events

rules.title: Obfuscated Files or Information Detection
rules.description: Detects obfuscated files or information used in ransomware attacks
falsepositives: Legitimate use of Base64 encoding in command lines

rules.title: Detection: Data from Local System
rules.description: Threat actors may collect data from local systems during ransomware attacks.

rules.title: Data Staging Detection
rules.description: Detects potential data staging activity by monitoring process creation and network connections

rules.title: Detection: Create or Modify System Process
rules.description: Detected Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Detection: Process Injection
rules.description: Detected Process Injection activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Obfuscated Files or Information Detection
rules.description: Detects obfuscated files or information using specific patterns for obfuscation
falsepositives: System administration tasks using encoded commands

rules.title: Detection: Archive Collected Data
rules.description: Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching

attacks.description: Encrypt a single test file using Windows Encrypting File System (EFS) via the built‑in cipher.exe utility.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file sample.txt in the %TEMP% directory is marked as encrypted; attempts to open it without the appropriate user credentials will fail, demonstrating data encryption for impact.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$key = (1..32 | ForEach-Object {Get-Random -Maximum 256}); $iv = (1..16 | ForEach-Object {Get-Random -Maximum 256}); $aes = New-Object System.Security.Cryptography.AesManaged; $aes.Key = $key; $aes.IV = $iv; Get-ChildItem -Path $env:TEMP -Filter *.txt -File | ForEach-Object { $plain = [System.IO.File]::ReadAllBytes($_.FullName); $encryptor = $aes.CreateEncryptor(); $ms = New-Object System.IO.MemoryStream; $cs = New-Object System.Security.Cryptography.CryptoStream($ms, $encryptor, [System.Security.Cryptography.CryptoStreamMode]::Write); $cs.Write($plain,0,$plain.Length); $cs.Close(); [System.IO.File]::WriteAllBytes($_.FullName, $ms.ToArray()) }"
attacks.description: PowerShell one‑liner that generates a random AES key/IV and encrypts every .txt file in the temporary directory, overwriting the originals.
attacks.expected_behavior: All .txt files under %TEMP% are replaced with AES‑encrypted ciphertext; the original plaintext is no longer recoverable without the generated key, emulating ransomware bulk encryption.

attacks.description: Encode a file to Base64 using certutil (a lightweight stand‑in for encryption) and then delete the original, renaming the encoded file to indicate it is locked.
attacks.expected_behavior: The original sample.txt is removed and replaced with sample.locked containing Base64 data, making the original content inaccessible and mimicking the destructive cleanup phase of ransomware.

attacks.description: Encrypt a single test file using OpenSSL symmetric encryption.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/secret.txt.enc containing the encrypted data; the original /tmp/secret.txt remains unchanged.

attacks.command: mkdir -p /tmp/data; for f in /tmp/data/*.txt; do openssl enc -aes-256-cbc -salt -in "$f" -out "$f.enc" -k TestPass; rm -f "$f"; done
attacks.description: Encrypt all .txt files in a test directory and remove the plaintext versions.
attacks.expected_behavior: Each .txt file in /tmp/data is replaced by an encrypted .enc file; the original plaintext files are deleted.

attacks.description: Download a file from a public web server using certutil, simulating retrieval of a malicious payload after exploiting a public‑facing application.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file 'malware.exe' is saved to the %TEMP% directory without being executed.

attacks.description: Send a crafted POST request to a vulnerable web‑application endpoint using PowerShell, representing exploitation of the public‑facing service.
attacks.expected_behavior: The request is transmitted to the target URL; no local files are created or modified.

attacks.command: sc create EvilService binPath= "%TEMP%\\malware.exe" start= auto && sc start EvilService
attacks.description: Create and start a Windows service that runs the previously downloaded payload, providing persistence after a successful exploit.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service named 'EvilService' is installed and started, executing the payload from %TEMP%\malware.exe.

attacks.description: Basic exploitation: send a crafted POST request that mimics an SQL injection attempt against a public login endpoint.
attacks.expected_behavior: The server receives the request and may log the suspicious parameters; no actual authentication is performed.

attacks.description: Intermediate exploitation: use netcat to send a raw HTTP request that attempts a directory‑traversal attack on a vulnerable Apache server.
attacks.expected_behavior: The target may respond with the contents of /etc/passwd if vulnerable; otherwise it returns a normal HTTP error.

attacks.description: Advanced exploitation: run an Nmap NSE script that checks for and exploits the Apache path‑traversal CVE‑2021‑41773 vulnerability on a public web service.
attacks.expected_behavior: Nmap scans the target, reports whether the vulnerability is present, and saves the results to nmap_scan.txt.

attacks.description: Deletes all Volume Shadow Copy snapshots to remove existing restore points and hinder file recovery.
attacks.expected_behavior: All existing shadow copies are removed; no further output is displayed.

attacks.description: Sets the DisableSR registry value to 1, disabling System Restore and preventing creation of new restore points.
attacks.expected_behavior: System Restore is disabled; the command returns a success message indicating the registry value was added.

attacks.description: Encrypts all files in the user's temporary directory, simulating ransomware encryption of user data.
attacks.expected_behavior: Files in %TEMP% become encrypted (EFS); attempting to open them without the proper key results in access denied.

attacks.description: Locate and delete any hidden snapshot directories within user home folders, which may contain point-in-time copies of data.
attacks.expected_behavior: All directories named .snapshot under /home are recursively removed, eliminating user-created snapshots.

attacks.description: Disable the system's rescue (recovery) target, preventing the use of 'systemctl rescue' or booting into rescue mode.
attacks.expected_behavior: The rescue.target unit is symlinked to /dev/null, effectively disabling it; subsequent attempts to enter rescue mode will fail.

attacks.description: Encrypt a single test file using Windows Encrypting File System (EFS) to simulate data manipulation by ransomware.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file %TEMP%\sample.txt becomes encrypted; attempts to open it without the proper user credentials will fail, indicating successful manipulation.

attacks.description: Overwrite all .log files in the temporary directory with a placeholder string, demonstrating data wiping/manipulation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Each .log file in %TEMP% has its contents replaced by the literal text 'DATA WIPED'.

attacks.description: Re‑encode a document via base64 and replace the original, effectively corrupting the file to emulate ransomware data manipulation.
attacks.expected_behavior: The original %TEMP%\important.docx is replaced with a version that has been base64‑encoded then decoded, resulting in corrupted content; opening the file will likely fail or display garbled data.

attacks.command: for f in /tmp/*.txt; do echo "=== WARNING: File has been modified ===" >> "$f"; done
attacks.description: Basic data manipulation: appends a warning line to each .txt file in /tmp.
attacks.expected_behavior: Each .txt file in /tmp receives an additional line at the end containing the warning message.

attacks.command: dd if=/dev/zero of=/tmp/important.dat bs=1K count=1 conv=notrunc status=none
attacks.description: Intermediate manipulation: overwrites the first 1 KB of a target file with zeros.
attacks.expected_behavior: The first 1024 bytes of /tmp/important.dat are replaced with null bytes, corrupting that portion of the file while leaving the rest intact.

attacks.command: for f in /var/log/*.log; do openssl enc -aes-256-cbc -salt -pbkdf2 -pass pass:TestPass123 -in "$f" -out "${f}.enc" && shred -u "$f"; done
attacks.description: Advanced manipulation: encrypts each .log file in /var/log with OpenSSL and securely deletes the original.
attacks.expected_behavior: All .log files under /var/log are encrypted to corresponding .enc files using AES‑256‑CBC with a test password, and the original log files are shredded (overwritten and removed).

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo This is a test > %TEMP%\plain.txt && certutil -encode %TEMP%\plain.txt %TEMP%\obf.txt && certutil -decode %TEMP%\obf.txt %TEMP%\decoded.txt"
attacks.description: Encode a plain text file to Base64 using certutil and then decode it back, demonstrating simple file obfuscation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\plain.txt with the test string, generates %TEMP%\obf.txt (Base64 encoded), and then produces %TEMP%\decoded.txt containing the original text.

attacks.description: Basic obfuscation: encodes a clear‑text string using Base64 and stores it in a temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file /tmp/obf_basic.txt is created containing the Base64 representation of "Sensitive data".

attacks.description: Intermediate obfuscation: reverses the string before Base64‑encoding, adding a simple transformation step.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file /tmp/obf_intermediate.txt is created containing the Base64 encoding of the reversed string "atad evitisneS".

attacks.command: echo "Sensitive data" | openssl enc -aes-256-cbc -salt -pass pass:mysecret -pbkdf2 | base64 > /tmp/obf_advanced.bin
attacks.description: Advanced obfuscation: encrypts the string with AES‑256‑CBC using a passphrase, then Base64‑encodes the binary ciphertext.
attacks.expected_behavior: A binary file /tmp/obf_advanced.bin is created containing the Base64‑encoded AES‑encrypted version of "Sensitive data".

attacks.description: Basic collection: copies a single user file from the Desktop to the temporary directory for later exfiltration.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file 'sample.txt' is duplicated as 'collected_sample.txt' in the %TEMP% folder. If the source file does not exist, the command fails silently without affecting the system.

attacks.description: Intermediate collection: uses certutil to base64‑encode a document, creating an encoded copy in %TEMP% for easier transport.
attacks.expected_behavior: The original 'secret.docx' remains unchanged while a new file 'secret.docx.b64' containing the base64 representation is written to %TEMP%. Errors (e.g., missing source file) are reported by certutil but no system changes occur.

attacks.description: Advanced collection: archives all files in the user's Documents folder into a zip file placed in %TEMP%, using PowerShell's built‑in compression cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip archive named 'documents.zip' containing the contents of the Documents directory is created in %TEMP%. Existing archive with the same name is overwritten due to -Force. No recursive system‑wide scan is performed.

attacks.description: Copies the /etc/passwd file, which contains user account information, to the current user's home directory for later exfiltration.
attacks.expected_behavior: A duplicate of /etc/passwd named passwd_copy will appear in the user's home directory.

attacks.description: Creates a compressed archive of authentication and system logs, which often contain credential and activity data, and stores it in the user's home directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A tar.gz file named collected_logs.tar.gz will be created in the home directory containing the specified log files.

attacks.command: dd if=/dev/sda of="$HOME/disk_image.img" bs=1M count=100 status=none
attacks.description: Creates a raw image of the first 100 MiB of the primary disk, capturing a snapshot of filesystem metadata and potentially sensitive data for later analysis.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named disk_image.img containing a 100 MiB raw disk image will be written to the user's home directory.

attacks.description: Creates a temporary staging directory and copies a benign test file into it.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new folder %TEMP%\staging is created (if it does not already exist) and the file example.txt is copied there. No changes to system files or privileges.

attacks.description: Compresses the staged files into a ZIP archive for later exfiltration or processing.
attacks.expected_behavior: All files in %TEMP%\staging are packaged into %TEMP%\staging.zip. The -Force flag overwrites any existing archive with the same name.

attacks.description: Encodes the ZIP archive to Base64 using certutil, creating a staged .b64 file suitable for text‑based transport.
attacks.expected_behavior: The binary ZIP file is transformed into a Base64‑encoded text file %TEMP%\staging.b64. No network activity occurs; the file remains on disk.

attacks.description: Adds a Run registry entry for the current user to launch Notepad at logon, creating a persistent system process.
attacks.expected_behavior: When the user logs on, Notepad.exe is started automatically via the Run key.

attacks.command: sc create TestService binPath= "\"%SystemRoot%\\System32\\notepad.exe\"" start= auto DisplayName= "Test Service"
attacks.description: Creates a new Windows service named TestService that runs Notepad.exe automatically, persisting a system process.
attacks.expected_behavior: The service starts at boot, launching Notepad.exe as a background process.

attacks.description: Creates a scheduled task that runs a PowerShell command to launch Notepad.exe on each user logon, establishing persistence via a system process.
attacks.expected_behavior: At every logon, the scheduled task triggers PowerShell, which starts Notepad.exe.

attacks.description: Create a simple script in /tmp and add an @reboot cron entry for the current user to execute it on system start.
attacks.expected_behavior: On the next reboot, the script runs and appends "Persistence test" to $HOME/persist.log; the cron entry persists across reboots.

attacks.command:
echo -e '[Unit]
Description=Test persistence service
After=network.target
[Service]
ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/persist.sh
Restart=always
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target' > /etc/systemd/system/persist.service && echo -e '#!/bin/bash
echo "Persistence test" >> /var/log/persist.log' > /usr/local/bin/persist.sh && chmod +x /usr/local/bin/persist.sh && systemctl daemon-reload && systemctl enable persist.service && systemctl start persist.service
attacks.description: Install a system‑wide systemd service that runs a script writing to /var/log, enable it to start at boot, and start it immediately.
attacks.expected_behavior: The new service is loaded, enabled for boot, and started now; it repeatedly writes "Persistence test" to /var/log/persist.log and will restart automatically if it exits.

attacks.description: Loads the user32.dll library with rundll32 and executes the MessageBoxW function, demonstrating a classic DLL injection technique.
attacks.expected_behavior: A message box titled 'Process Injection Demo' with text 'Test' appears, indicating the DLL was successfully loaded and executed.

attacks.description: Creates an empty dummy DLL, launches notepad, captures its PID, and attempts to load the dummy DLL with rundll32 – a typical multi‑step injection workflow.
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad starts, the dummy DLL file is written to %TEMP%, and rundll32 is invoked (the DLL has no entry point, so no visible effect). The command demonstrates the injection steps without harming the system.

attacks.command: powershell -Command \"$dll = [System.IO.Path]::Combine($env:TEMP, 'payload.dll'); # placeholder for benign DLL; $proc = Start-Process notepad.exe -PassThru; $pid = $proc.Id; Write-Host \\\"[ADV] Simulated CreateRemoteThread injection into PID $pid using $dll\\\"\"
attacks.description: Simulates an advanced CreateRemoteThread injection: prepares a benign DLL path, starts a target process, retrieves its PID, and logs a message representing the injection action.
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad launches; PowerShell outputs a line like '[ADV] Simulated CreateRemoteThread injection into PID 1234 using C:\Users\...\payload.dll', indicating the steps an attacker would perform.

attacks.description: Basic process injection using gdb to call dlopen() in a running process, loading a shared library into the target.
attacks.expected_behavior: The target process (PID 1234) loads /tmp/mylib.so; gdb exits without visible output.

attacks.description: Intermediate injection by preloading a shared library when launching a new process (ls), causing the library to be mapped into the process address space.
attacks.expected_behavior: ls lists the contents of /tmp; the preloaded library is loaded into the ls process (benign in this test).

attacks.description: Advanced injection using gdb to invoke system() inside the target process, causing it to execute an arbitrary command (echo).
attacks.expected_behavior: The target process runs '/bin/echo injected', printing 'injected' to its stdout (may not be visible to the attacker).

attacks.description: Executes a PowerShell command encoded in Base64 (UTF‑16LE). The decoded command is 'Get-Process', which lists running processes, demonstrating command‑level obfuscation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of currently running processes in the console.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo @echo off > %TEMP%\\hello.bat && echo echo Hello World >> %TEMP%\\hello.bat && certutil -encode %TEMP%\\hello.bat %TEMP%\\hello.b64 >nul && certutil -decode %TEMP%\\hello.b64 %TEMP%\\hello_decoded.bat >nul && cmd.exe /c %TEMP%\\hello_decoded.bat"
attacks.description: Creates a simple batch file, encodes it with certutil (Base64), then decodes it at runtime and executes it. The use of certutil for encoding/decoding hides the script content, illustrating file‑level obfuscation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs 'Hello World' to the console after decoding and running the hidden batch file.

attacks.description: Stores a Base64‑encoded PowerShell script in a variable, decodes it at runtime, and executes it via Invoke-Expression. The encoded payload runs 'whoami', showing layered obfuscation of script content.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints the current user name to the console.

attacks.description: Decodes a Base64‑encoded string that contains a benign echo command and executes it via bash, hiding the actual command text.
attacks.expected_behavior: The Base64 string decodes to `echo "Hello, Obfuscated World!"` and prints the message to stdout.

attacks.description: Decrypts an AES‑256‑CBC encrypted script stored in /tmp/obf_script.enc using a known password and pipes the plaintext to bash, obscuring the script content at rest.
attacks.expected_behavior: Assuming /tmp/obf_script.enc contains an encrypted `echo "Encrypted Execution"` script, decryption yields the command which is then executed, printing the message.

attacks.description: Reads a ROT13‑encoded script file, transforms it back to plain text using tr, and executes it, demonstrating simple character substitution obfuscation.
attacks.expected_behavior: If /tmp/rot13_script.txt contains `rfgre "Rkgenpgvir Vffhr"`, the tr command decodes it to `echo "Encrypted Success"` which is then run, outputting the message.

attacks.description: Creates a simple text file and compresses it into a zip archive using PowerShell's Compress-Archive cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named sample.txt is written to the TEMP directory, then a zip file sample.zip containing that file is created in the same directory.

attacks.command: cmd /c "echo Log1 > %TEMP%\log1.txt && echo Log2 > %TEMP%\log2.txt && tar -a -c -f %TEMP%\logs.zip -C %TEMP% log1.txt log2.txt"
attacks.description: Generates two log files and archives them into a zip file using the built‑in tar utility.
attacks.expected_behavior: Two text files (log1.txt and log2.txt) are created in the TEMP folder, then a zip archive logs.zip containing both files is produced in the same folder.

attacks.description: Writes a sample data file to the user's AppData directory and archives it into a cabinet (.cab) file using the legacy makecab utility.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named CollectedData.txt is created in the AppData folder, then makecab creates a cabinet archive CollectedData.cab in the TEMP directory containing that file.

attacks.description: Basic archive creation using tar without compression.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/data_archive.tar containing the file /tmp/collected_data.txt.

attacks.description: Intermediate archive with gzip compression and directory change.
attacks.expected_behavior: Produces a compressed archive /tmp/data_archive.tar.gz that includes collected_data.txt and logs.log from /tmp.

attacks.description: Advanced archive using zip with a password for simple encryption.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/data_archive.zip containing the two files, protected with the password 'TestPass123'.
